Key Arguments: The bill poses a threat to democracy and freedom of speech.
Misinformation and disinformation are subjective labels that can be used for censorship.
Historical examples show that ideas initially labeled as misinformation can lead to scientific breakthroughs.
The bill assumes ACMA has the ability to accurately identify misinformation, which is unrealistic.
Government and media, which can also spread misinformation, are exempt from the bill.
Notable Quotes: Combatting so-called misinformation and disinformation poses a threat to the safety and wellbeing of Australians, as well as to our democracy, society and economy.
Stifling ideas stifles democracy and science.
The risk of government, through ACMA, labelling and censoring ideas, and de-platforming the people who espouse them...is far more serious than any risk from incorrect information on the internet.
